SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Anna Adeline Olson

2. Your address: 1625 Reddecker Street, Regina, Sask.

3. Date: October 15, 1966.

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Mariopol Township, Oakwood, Ontario.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Savinac - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): September 13, 1907

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Lived in Ontario till 1907.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 21 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To take up homestead and try to better myself.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) One at $1600 acres of land for $10.00.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Anna Adeline Olson

2. Your address: 1675 Ratcliff Street, Regina, Sask.

3. Date: October 15, 1965

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Marspoa Township, Ontario

5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Svilta - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): September 15, 1907

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Lived in Ontario till 1907.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 21 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To take up homestead and try to better ourselves.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Could get 160 acres of land for $10.00.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They tried to stop us and said we would either freeze or starve to death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   I traveled with a seven month baby, as husband was here before me.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   U.N.R. to Drift Sack, and the last 17 miles with a team of mules.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Found people friendly and helpful.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   At a place called Foota, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? In the Foota district and Luteran.
   In 1911 moved three miles from Long Lake on East Mountain Lake.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Regina.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Farming.
2.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They tried to stop us and said we would either freeze or starve to death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    I traveled with a seven month baby, as husband was here before me.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    C.N.R. to Qu'Appelle, and the last 17 miles with a team of mules.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    Found people friendly and helpful.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    At a place called Pootie, 3882.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? In the Pootie district land last year.
    In 1911 moved three miles from Long Lake on Last Mountain Lake.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    Regina.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
    Farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Every week for was very lonesome for we had no relatives here.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Jesse Rodd, married in 1905 in Toronto, Ontario.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   No.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.
   None of my family came.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   The mosquitoes nearly ate us alive, and the hard times we had to break the sod with horses and so many rocks to pick. There was a shortage of water and had to drink slough water. When I was 22 years old I was called on to be a midwife as the nearest doctor was 17 miles away. I liked the West but my husband was so homesick he would have sold out for 25 cents but no one had any money.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Went back to Ontario quite often to visit parents and friends on the train.
3.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? The mosquito was particularly bad, and the herd times needed to break the soil with horses and so many risks to take. There was a shortage of water and had to drink through water. When I was 22 years old I was called on to be a midwife as the nearest doctor was 17 miles away. I liked the West but my husband was so homesick he would have sold out for 25 cents but I fought him any money.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? Went back to Ontario quite often to visit parents and friends on the train.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1912.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? No.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Oralik, Sask. It was 17 miles from home.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) Traded there till the C.P.R. came through in 1911 and we had villages every 11 miles and then we had a place called Zanana to trade in.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Every week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? As soon as the Ballito came through in 1911.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period. We first started to buy through the catalogue in 1907. We bought clothing, hardware and groceries at things were so expensive at Oralik. We bought about three fourths of our living through the catalogue.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? We got our first phone in 1914, it was the Bell Company.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Yes Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? We decided when we left Ontario to stay permanently.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1913.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? No.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Urik, Salford. It was 17 miles from home.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing; better means of travel, etc.) Traded there till the C.P.R. came through in 1911 and was new villages grew 11 miles and then we had a place called Zanana to trade in.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Every week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? We didn't use the railroad close through in 1911.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We first started to buy through the catalogue in 1907. We bought small things like clothing, hardware and groceries by this method. We bought about three cents each article.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? We got our first phone in 1914; it was the Bell Company.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Yes Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? We decided when we left Ontario to stay permanently.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No, the people didn't move away as they didn't have any money to move anywhere.

34. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, a few.

35. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

N/A

36. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

N/A

37. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The names got their names through the English settlers came from. The first offices named after the land where the settlers came from. The first offices named after the people that kept it. When the railroads were named after the names of the towns were changed.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No, the records didn't show anyone who moved away.

34. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, a few.

35. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Nil.

36. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Nil.

37. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The places got their names through the English Surveyors. The streets were named after the place where the settlers came from. The Post Office was named after the people that built it. When the railroad went through the names of the places were changed to the names of the villages.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)

40. Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office of the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

One child - Mrs. Stella Jackson, 1675 Retail Park Street, Regina.

Two grandchildren - Mr. Donald Jackson, 10851 100th Street, Regina.
